questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents after a motor vehicle accident with a clavicle fracture. During surgery, the surgeon carefully avoids damaging nearby blood vessels, including those from the thyrocervical trunk. Which artery is not a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and is less likely to be encountered during this procedure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Dorsal Scapular Artery Explanation: Dorsal Scapular Artery arises from the third part of the subclavian artery or may originate from the transverse cervical artery , but it is not a branch of the thyrocervical trunk. Thyrocervical trunk , a branch of the subclavian artery, typically gives rise to three main branches: Inferior thyroid artery Suprascapular artery Transverse cervical artery (also called superficial cervical artery) Subclavian artery : Right Subclavian Artery: From the brachiocephalic trunk (posterior or superior to the right sternoclavicular joint). Left Subclavian Artery: Directly from the arch of the aorta (after the brachiocephalic trunk and left common carotid artery). Clinical Significance of Subclavian artery: Palpation and Compression: Can be palpated in the supraclavicular triangle; compressed to control upper limb bleeding. Subclavian Steal Syndrome: Proximal narrowing of the subclavian artery leads to retrograde flow, which can cause dizziness or arm fatigue. Thoracic Outlet Syndrome: Compression of the subclavian artery and the lower part of the brachial plexus (joined at the first rib by the subclavian vessels) in this condition can cause pain, numbness, or weakness in the arm or hand.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man undergoes surgery for a tumour in the axilla. During the procedure, the surgeon identifies the second part of the axillary artery and its branches. Which of the following arteries arises from this segment of the axillary artery and must be carefully preserved during the dissection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Thoraco-acromial artery Explanation: Axillary artery is divided into three parts based on its position relative to the pectoralis minor muscle : First is medial, the second is behind, and the third is lateral to the muscle. Thoracoacromial artery arises from the second part of the axillary artery, which is located posterior to the pectoralis minor muscle. Superior thoracic artery arises from the first part , while the subscapular and anterior circumflex humeral arteries arise from the third part.

questions.question: The following image illustrates the blood supply to the mammary gland. Identify the artery labelled "A."
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Internal Thoracic Artery Explanation: The artery labeled "A" in the image is the Internal Thoracic Artery . Internal thoracic artery supplies the anteromedial part of the breast through its medial mammary branches. Blood supply of the Mammary gland Source of Blood Supply Arteries Description Internal Thoracic Artery (Option B) Medial Mammary Branches Originates from the subclavian artery and supplies the anteromedial part of the breast. Axillary Artery Lateral Thoracic Artery (Option A) It gives off lateral mammary branches to supply the lateral aspect of the breast. Subscapular Artery (Option D) Contributes to the blood supply to lateral and posterior aspects of the breast Anterior Intercostal Arteries (Option C) 2nd to 4th Intercostal Arteries Enlarges during lactation; Supplies superior regions of the breast

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with a shoulder injury following a fall. During a physical examination, the physician palpates the brachial artery to assess the blood supply to the arm. At which anatomical landmark does this artery begin as a continuation of the axillary artery?

options.A: Lower border of the teres minor
options.B: Upper border of the teres major
options.C: Lower border of the teres major
options.D: Upper border of the teres minor

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Lower border of the teres major Explanation: Brachial artery is a vital artery in the upper limb originating at the lower border of the teres major muscle and is a direct continuation of the axillary artery. Brachial Artery Aspect Description Origin Continuation of the axillary artery at the inferior border of the teres major muscle. Course Courses distally, spiralling from medial to anterior, lying midway between the medial and lateral epicondyles of the humerus. Terminates about 1 cm distal to the elbow into radial and ulnar arteries. Major Branches Profunda Brachii Artery : Supplies posterior compartment muscles. Nutrient Artery: Supplies the humerus. Superior Ulnar Collateral Artery: Anastomoses with posterior ulnar recurrent artery. Inferior Ulnar Collateral Artery: Anastomoses with anterior ulnar recurrent artery. Deltoid Artery: Supplies the deltoid muscle. Muscular Arteries: Supply various arm muscles. Radial Artery: Supplies the lateral forearm and contributes to the palmar arch. Ulnar Artery: Supplies the medial forearm and contributes to the palmar arch.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with intermittent pain and numbness in his right hand, especially after gripping. The physician suspects vascular insufficiency. Which test is the physician likely to perform to assess the blood supply to the hand?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Allen's test Explanation: Allen's test evaluates the patency of the radial and ulnar arteries supplying the hand. Allens test: The examiner compresses both arteries at the wrist while the patient clenches their fist to drain blood from the hand. Subsequently, pressure on one artery is released, and the return of hand colour is observed. A rapid colour return indicates an adequate blood supply from that artery. It ensures an adequate collateral circulation and is especially useful before procedures such as arterial blood gas sampling or harvesting the radial artery for grafting. Phalen's test (Option B) assesses carpal tunnel syndrome . The patient flexes their wrists by pressing the backs of their hands together for 60 seconds . A positive test results in tingling, numbness, or pain in the median nerve distribution, suggesting carpal tunnel compression. Tinel's sign (OptionC) is another test for carpal tunnel syndrome. The examiner taps over the median nerve at the wrist. If this elicits a tingling or "pins and needles" sensation in the fingers supplied by the median nerve , it indicates nerve irritation or damage. Capillary refill test (Option D) assesses peripheral perfusion and circulatory status . The examiner presses on the nail bed or skin until it blanches (turns white), then releases. A normal capillary refill time is less than 2 seconds , which indicates adequate blood flow.

questions.question: A 72-year-old male with a history of atherosclerosis and hypertension presents with sudden severe pain, numbness, and weakness in his left arm. Examination shows difficulty gripping and sensory loss in the hand. Which anastomosis is most critical for collateral blood flow to the left upper limb in this condition?

options.A: Suprascapular artery and dorsal scapular artery
options.B: Subscapular artery and circumflex scapular artery
options.C: Superior thoracic artery and acromiothoracic artery
options.D: Suprascapular artery and circumflex scapular artery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Suprascapular artery and circumflex scapular artery Explanation: The scenario describes a case of subclavian artery occlusion , in which the suprascapular artery (branch of subclavian artery) and the circumflex scapular artery (branch of axillary artery) form the most critical anastomosis for ensuring collateral blood flow to the upper limb. Anastomosis of the Scapula: It is formed between the branches of the 1st part of the subclavian artery and the 3rd part of the axillary artery at the following two locations: Around the body of the scapula Over the acromion process Suprascapular artery (branch of the thyrocervical trunk) Circumflex scapular artery (branch of the subscapular artery from the 3rd part of the axillary artery) Deep branch of the transverse cervical artery (branch of the thyrocervical trunk). Acromial branch of the thoracoacromial artery (2nd part of axillary). Acromial branch of the suprascapular artery (1st part of subclavian). Acromial branch of the posterior circumflex humeral artery (3rd part of axillary). Collateral circulation through scapular anastomosis: The arterial anastomoses (scapular) provide collateral circulation through which blood can flow to the limb when the subclavian or axillary artery is blocked (anywhere between 1st part of the subclavian artery and 3rd part of axillary artery). Suprascapular artery and dorsal scapular artery (Option A) are the branches of the thyrocervical trunk and transverse cervical artery , respectively; both are subclavian artery branches. Subscapular and circumflex scapular arteries (Option B) are branches of the 3rd part of the axillary artery. Superior thoracic artery and acromiothoracic artery (Option C) are axillary artery branches from the 1st and 2nd part , respectively.

questions.question: A patient with stage 5 chronic kidney disease is preparing for hemodialysis. During the examination, tenderness is noted in the right arm, and a prominent vein is visible. The doctor asks the intern to identify the vein, hinting that it pierces the clavipectoral fascia. What vein is being referenced?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Cephalic vein Explanation: Cephalic vein is the preferred choice for hemodialysis in cases of renal failure. It pierces the clavipectoral fascia before its termination. Superficial veins of the upper limb: Deep veins of the upper limb: Begin as small venae comitantes alongside the digital veins, which then continue proximally to form the superficial and deep palmar arches . Venae comitantes , which accompany radial, ulnar, and brachial arteries Venae comitantes of the brachial artery Axillary vein (continuation of the basilic vein, drains into the subclavian vein)

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents to the clinic following her mammogram results, revealing a palpable mass in her left breast and mild discomfort. Examination shows enlarged lymph nodes in the left axilla. Which of the following is the terminal group of axillary lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Apical Explanation: The apical group of lymph nodes is the terminal group of axillary lymph nodes. Lymphatic Drainage of the Mammary Gland: It includes: Lymph nodes and lymphatic vessels Subdiaphragmatic and subperitoneal lymph plexuses Drainage: Lymph Nodes/Plexus Part of breast Anterior axillary or pectoral group of lymph nodes (Option B) Lateral quadrants Internal mammary lymph nodes Medial quadrants Posterior intercostal nodes Lower lateral quadrant Subdiaphragmatic and subperitoneal lymph plexuses Lower medial quadrant Apical group of axillary lymph nodes (Option C) Deep surface Subareolar plexus of Sappey is a network of lymphatic vessels located deep in the areola, which primarily drains lymphatic fluid from the breast into the anterior (pectoral) group of lymph nodes. Axillary lymph nodes drain into supraclavicular lymph nodes. (Option D) Clinical Significance: “Peau d’orange” appearance of the skin in the breast carcinoma due to obstruction of superficial lymphatics. Krukenberg’s tumour occurs when lymphatic vessels from the breast connect with the subperitoneal lymph plexus, allowing cancer cells to travel to the ovaries and form a secondary tumour.

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department with swelling and pain in his right hand, particularly around the base of the thumb, after puncturing it with a nail. Examination shows tenderness, swelling, and limited thumb movement. An infection is diagnosed. Which statement about this space is incorrect?

options.B: Infection can spread through the radial bursa
options.C: Associated short muscles of thumb anteriorly
options.D: Anterior wall is formed by the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Anterior wall is formed by the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals Explanation: The case is diagnosed as an infection of the thenar space , where the 1st lumbrical forms the anterior wall , while the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th lumbricals constitute the anterior wall of the mid-palmar space. Midpalmar Space vs Thenar Space: Aspect Midpalmar Space Thenar Space Shape Triangular Triangular (Option A) Site Under the inner half of the hollow of the palm Under the outer half of the hollow of the palm Extent Distal margin of the flexor retinaculum (proximal) Distal palmar crease (distal) Distal margin of the flexor retinaculum (proximal) Proximal transverse palmar crease (distal) Communications Forearm space of Parona (proximal) Fascial sheaths of the 3rd and 4th lumbricals (distal) Forearm space of Parona (proximal) The fascial sheath of the first lumbrical (distal) Anterior wall Palmar aponeurosis Flexor tendons of 3rd, 4th and 5th digits Medial three ( 2nd, 3rd, and 4th ) lumbricals (Option D) Short muscles of the thumb (Option C) Flexor tendons of the index finger 1st lumbrical Palmar aponeurosis Posterior wall Fascia covering interossei and metacarpals Transverse head of adductor pollicis Lateral wall Intermediate palmar septum Tendon of flexor pollicis longus with radial bursa Lateral palmar septum Medial wall Medial palmar septum Intermediate palmar septum Infection inlet Ulnar bursa Radial bursa (Option B) Synovial sheath of the index finger Incision for drainage 3rd or 4th web space 1st web (posteriorly)

questions.question: A teenager presents with severe pain and swelling in the tip of her right index finger after slamming it into a door. Examination reveals significant swelling, erythema, tenderness, increased sensitivity, and difficulty moving the finger. An infection of the structure marked ‘X’ is diagnosed. What is most likely?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Felon Explanation: The given scenario is a case of Felon or infection in the Digital Pulp Space , labelled as “X” in the image. The tips of the fingers and thumb contain subcutaneous fat organised into compartments, separated by fibrous septa extending to the terminal phalanx's periosteum. Drainage procedure: A lateral incision should be made to access all loculi while carefully preserving tactile sensation on the dorsal aspect of the finger. Complication: AVN ( avascular necrosis ) of distal 4-5th of the terminal phalanx due to occlusion of the digital artery due to pressure. Herpetic Whitlow (Option A) is a viral infection characterised by painful blisters on the fingertip. It typically follows exposure to the herpes virus rather than trauma. It usually presents with vesicular lesions rather than localised swelling and tenderness. Paronychia (Option C) affects the nail fold and presents with redness, swelling, and pain around the nail margin. It does not involve the digital pulp space and is not typically associated with severe fingertip swelling. Tendon Sheath Infection (Option D) involves the flexor tendon sheath and presents with diffuse swelling, pain, and difficulty moving the entire finger. It

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient is undergoing surgery on the forearm. During the procedure, the surgeon ligates the brachial artery near the elbow. Which anastomotic site helps maintain blood flow to the forearm?

options.A: In front of the lateral epicondyle
options.C: In front of the medial epicondyle

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) In front of the medial epicondyle Explanation: In front of the medial epicondyle : This anastomosis (inferior ulnar collateral ↔ anterior ulnar recurrent) ensures adequate blood flow to the forearm when the brachial artery is ligated near the elbow. Anastomoses Around the Elbow Joint: It Links brachial artery with upper ends of radial and ulnar arteries. Supply ligaments and bones of the elbow joint. Anastomotic Locations : In Front of the Lateral Epicondyle: Radial Collateral (Profunda Brachii) ↔ Radial Recurrent (Radial Artery). Behind the Lateral Epicondyle : Middle Collateral (Profunda Brachii) ↔ Interosseous Recurrent (Posterior Interosseous Artery). In Front of the Medial Epicondyle : Inferior Ulnar Collateral (Brachial Artery) ↔ Anterior Ulnar Recurrent (Ulnar Artery). Behind the Medial Epicondyle : Superior Ulnar Collateral (Brachial Artery) ↔ Posterior Ulnar Recurrent (Ulnar Artery). Clinical Relevance : Brachial Pulsation : Palpated medial to the biceps tendon in front of the elbow for blood pressure measurement. Brachial Compression : Best applied mid-arm (over coracobrachialis tendon) for hemostasis. Blood Collection : Brachial artery is a site for blood gas analysis. In front of the lateral epicondyle (Option A) : Involves radial collateral and radial recurrent arteries, which supply lateral elbow structures but not sufficient for forearm. Behind the lateral epicondyle (Option B) : Middle collateral and interosseous recurrent arteries provide supply behind the elbow but do not compensate fully for brachial artery ligation. Behind the medial epicondyle (Option D) : Superior ulnar collateral and posterior ulnar recurrent arteries supply posterior elbow , not anterior forearm structures.

questions.question: A patient sustains a deep laceration to the palm, resulting in significant bleeding. The surgeon identifies damage to an arterial structure located superficial to the flexor tendons and supplying the medial 3½ digits. Which arterial structure is most likely injured?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Superficial palmar arch Explanation: Superficial palmar arch is located deep to the palmar aponeurosis but superficial to the flexor tendons , and it supplies the medial 3½ digits via its common digital branches. Superficial Palmar Arch Deep Palmar Arch Anastomosis Between ulnar and radial arteries. Between radial and ulnar arteries. Location Deep to palmaris brevis and aponeurosis. Crosses palm over flexor tendons and median nerve Deep to flexor tendons, on proximal metacarpals and interossei. Formed by Ulnar artery (superficial branch) and radial artery (superficial branch). Radial artery (terminal part) and ulnar artery (deep branch). Branches Three common digital arteries (medial 3½ digits). One proper digital branch. Lateral digital branches join palmar metacarpal arteries from deep arch. Three palmar metacarpal arteries (supply medial metacarpals). Three perforating digital arteries (anastomose with dorsal metacarpal arteries). Recurrent branch (supplies carpal bones and joints, ends in palmar carpal arch). Deep palmar arch (Option B) : Lies deep to the flexor tendons and primarily supplies the proximal metacarpals, not the medial 3½ digits. Radial artery (Option C) : Supplies the lateral side of the forearm and hand but does not provide primary branches to the medial digits. Ulnar artery (Option D) : Contributes to the superficial palmar arch but does not directly supply the medial digits; damage here would involve the arch rather than the artery itself.

questions.question: A 28-year-old patient presents with weakness in thumb flexion and loss of forearm pronation after a deep laceration to the anterior forearm. Imaging reveals disruption of an artery accompanying the anterior interosseous nerve. Which artery is most likely damaged?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Anterior interosseous artery Explanation: Anterior interosseous artery runs with the anterior interosseous nerve along the interosseous membrane, supplying deep forearm muscles like the flexor pollicis longus and pronator quadratus. Injury here matches the clinical findings of impaired thumb flexion and pronation. Interosseous Membrane and Arteries: Common Interosseous Artery : Arises below the radial tuberosity, divides into anterior and posterior interosseous arteries. Anterior Interosseous Artery : Deep artery on the forearm, runs along the interosseous membrane with the anterior interosseous nerve. Pierces the membrane at the pronator quadratus to enter the extensor compartment. Branches: Muscular branches, nutrient branches to radius and ulna, median artery with the median nerve. Posterior Interosseous Artery : Gives off interosseous recurrent artery (anastomoses with middle collateral artery). Passes through a gap in the interosseous membrane to the back of the forearm. Radial artery (Option A) : Supplies the lateral forearm and hand but does not accompany the anterior interosseous nerve or supply the affected muscles. Common interosseous artery (Option B) : Divides into anterior and posterior interosseous arteries early and does not accompany the nerve to the forearm. Posterior interosseous artery (Option D) : Supplies extensor muscles of the forearm and is unrelated to the anterior compartment or anterior interosseous nerve. Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page 121 Grey's Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Page 1464.e91

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the median cubital vein is incorrect?

options.A: It connects the cephalic vein to the basilic vein.
options.B: It runs obliquely downward and laterally across the forearm.
options.C: It is superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis, which separates it from the brachial artery.
options.D: It is the primary choice for venipuncture and catheterization due to its stability.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) It runs obliquely downward and laterally across the forearm. Explanation: Median cubital vein runs obliquely upward and medially , not downward and laterally Median Cubital Vein: Anatomy : Connects cephalic to basilic vein. (Option A ruled out) Origin: Cephalic vein (2.5 cm below elbow). Ends: Basilic vein (2.5 cm above medial epicondyle). Runs obliquely upward and medially. Relations : Superficial to bicipital aponeurosis (separating it from brachial artery). (Option C ruled out) Receives tributaries from the median forearm vein. Stabilized by a perforator vein connecting to deep veins. Clinical Significance : Primary Choice : Ideal for venipuncture and catheterization due to stability. (Option D ruled out) Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page 89

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with breast cancer presents with enlarged lymph nodes in her axilla. Biopsy reveals metastatic spread. Which group of axillary lymph nodes is most likely the initial site of cancer drainage?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anterior (Pectoral) nodes Explanation: Anterior (pectoral) nodes are located along the lateral thoracic vessels and primarily drain the anterior trunk wall and breast , making them the first site for lymphatic drainage from breast tissue. Axillary Lymph Nodes: 20-30 nodes in axillary fibrofatty tissue. Divided into five groups based on location and drainage. Groups : Anterior (Pectoral) : Along lateral thoracic vessels; drains anterior trunk wall and breast. Posterior (Scapular) : Along subscapular vessels; drains posterior trunk wall and axillary breast tail. Lateral : Medial to axillary vein; drains upper limb. Central : In axillary fat; drains anterior, posterior, and lateral groups. Apical (Infraclavicular) : Behind pectoralis minor; drains central nodes, upper breast, and thumb. Clinical Importance : Drains upper limb, breast, and body walls above the umbilicus. Common site for infections and malignancies (e.g., breast cancer). Axillary Abscess : Incision through axillary floor near medial wall to avoid vessels. Posterior (Scapular) nodes (Option B) : Drains the posterior trunk wall and the axillary tail of the breast; unlikely to be the first site of drainage for the main breast tissue. Lateral nodes (Option C) : Drains the upper limb and does not directly receive lymph from the breast. Apical (Infraclavicular) nodes (Option D) : Drains central nodes and other axillary groups but is not the initial site for primary breast lymphatic drainage.
